Just as the title says! Starting this morning, I'm creating a series of tutorial videos and throwing them up on YouTube to help our new and amateur Kerbonauts doing what they want.

I'm starting off with basic game mechanics and moving on to more advanced maneuvers as I go along/learn them. Some people don't understand the vague guides posted, so I attempt to translate them in my brain and put them in Layman's terms.

If you appreciate my work and find it helpful please don't hesitate to share it with anyone else who might find it helpful. The first video in the series is pretty lengthy and I babble a lot, but I'll try to cut that down in future additions. It's also in 1080p

I appreciate it. One of the things I had trouble with other tutorials was too much of the information was "skipped" or it's assumed that certain things are already understood when they're not.

As far as landers go, try using things that aren't too tall so they don't tip over, and make sure you use appropriate sized landing legs so they don't break. Other than that, I'm not sure what exactly you're having trouble with but if you want to drop me a private message on the forums I'd be glad to do my best to help you out.

Landing is on something like the Mun is a delicate thing. You can get away with really fast burns to change your orbits, but trying to land with quick burns is a recipe for disaster. Slooooow, loooooong burns at precise angles is the name of the game. I use MechJeb to assist me in this; the actual landing autopilot is way too far off for my purposes, but using a combination of the Translatron's KEEP VERT function and Smart A.S.S., using SURF for most of the way, and RETR GRAD when I'm really close and want to set-down, I can usually land within +/- 1 degree of latitude and longitude of my intended landing site.

Of course, it is entirely possible to land without MechJeb's help, but goodness does it ever make life easier by taking the load off your brain. CRM (Cockpit Resource Management, which basically means having multiple people do different tasks so no one gets distracted by task switching or focusing too much on one thing, and every necessary task is completed) doesn't really exist in a game where there's only one pilot.
